Long Description: Jean-Jacques Rousseau in Armenian costume. This portrait was painted when Rousseau was in exile in London as a guest of the Scottish thinker David Hume. "This sympathetic portrait of Rousseau in Armenian costume was painted by the highly talented Scottish artist Allan Ramsay. Rousseau's unusual clothing aroused great curiosity on his arrival in London and this picture gives a very good idea of the fascination it provoked. Ramsay planned the portrait as a gift to his close personal friend and fellow Scot, David Hume. Hume, who was himself an internationally eminent Enlightenment philosopher and historian, had facilitated Rousseau's escape from France to Britain in 1766. He also found him somewhere to stay and secured a pension for him from King George III. Ramsay painted a portrait of Hume as a companion to this picture, to hang in Hume's own home (also NGS [Scottish National Portrait Gallery]). Sadly, the friendship which helped to generate this sensitive portrait very quickly soured. Rousseau quarrelled publically with his Scottish host and this affected his view of this portrait.

Long Description: Princess Augusta of Saxe-Gotha-Altenburg (30 November [O.S. 19 November] 1719 – 8 February 1772)[1] was Princess of Wales by marriage to Frederick, Prince of Wales. She was one of only four Princesses of Wales who never became queen consort, as her eldest son succeeded her father-in-law as George III of the United Kingdom in 1760 rather than her spouse, who had died nine years earlier. Augusta was presumptive regent of Great Britain in the event of a regency between the death of her spouse in 1751, until the majority of her son in 1756, though in the event her father-in-law, George II, lived until 1760.

Long Description: This is the prime versions of Ramsay's State Portrait of George III in coronation robes. His coronation took place on 22 September 1761. The Scottish artist had already painted the sitter as Prince of Wales in 1758 for John Stuart, 3rd Earl of Bute, Ramsay's most important patron in London and George III's tutor and mentor. The success of that portrait and of a portrait of Bute (both Mount Stuart, Isle of Bute), led to this major commission. Ramsay wrote in 1766: 'I painted, from the life, a whole length picture of him for Hanover, a profile for the coinage, and another whole length which after the Coronation, I, by his Majesties orders dressed in Coronation robes. Soon after her Majesty's arrival, she likewise did me the honour to sit to me; and these two pictures in coronation robes are the originals from which all the copies ordered by the Lord Chamberlain are painted.' In December 1761 Ramsay reported to Lord Bute that he was also working on a version in coronation robes for Hanover and one for Lord Bute (Mount Stuart, Isle of Bute). Walpole recorded seeing the painting (presumably this one) in March 1762, 'painted exactly from the very robes which the king wore at his coronation'.

Long Description: One of his drawing pupils was Margaret Lindsay, eldest daughter of Sir Alexander Lindsay of Evelick and Amelia Murray (granddaughter to David Murray, 5th Viscount of Stormont and sister to the naval officer John Lindsay). He later eloped with her and on 1 March 1752 they married in the Canongate Kirk, Edinburgh; her father never forgave her for marrying an artist. Ramsay already had to maintain a daughter from his previous marriage and his two surviving sisters, but told Sir Alexander that he could provide Margaret with an annual income of £100. He said it would increase ‘as my affairs increase, and I thank God, they are in a way of increasing’ and that his only motive for the marriage was ‘my love for your Daughter, who, I am sensible, is entitled to much more than ever I shall have to bestow upon her’.[3] Three children survived from their long and happy marriage, Amelia (1755–1813), Charlotte (1758–1818?), and John (1768–1845).

Long Description: Previously thought to be a self-portrait of Gavin Hamilton, this drawing has since been identified as a work by Ozias Humphry of 1777. Hamilton spent most of his life in Rome where he worked as an artist, his style influenced by the antiquities that surrounded him. In addition to painting, he dealt in classical statuary, much of which he excavated himself. Between 1758 and 1777 he worked on a grand scheme of six large history paintings, their subjects inspired by Homer's Iliad, two of which are now in the collection of the National Galleries of Scotland. Through his own art, his antiques dealing and his assistance to young artists, Hamilton became a pivotal figure in the artistic life of Rome in the second half of the 18th century, and helped establish a taste for Neoclassicism in Europe.

Title: The Conjuror
Short description: Nathaniel Hone established a successful career as a fashionable portrait and subject painter in London. This beautifully executed satirical painting (the full title of which is 'The Pictorial Conjuror, Displaying the Whole Art of Optical Deception') caused an outcry when it was submitted by the artist for exhibition at the Royal Academy, London, in 1775. The reason given was that included in the picture was a nude caricature of the Swiss painter Angelica Kauffman. This was subsequently painted over, but the original figure can still be seen in a sketch in Tate Britain. The true cause of offence, however, was that the picture was seen as an attack on Kauffman's friend Joshua Reynolds, President of the Royal Academy. His practice of borrowing poses from Old Master paintings to ennoble his portraits was seen by Hone as plagiarism.
Keywords: Nathaniel Hone The Conjurer, painting, oil on canvas, National Gallery of Ireland, Nathaniel Hone the Elder
Long Description: Nathaniel Hone established a successful career as a fashionable portrait and subject painter in London. This beautifully executed satirical painting (the full title of which is 'The Pictorial Conjuror, Displaying the Whole Art of Optical Deception') caused an outcry when it was submitted by the artist for exhibition at the Royal Academy, London, in 1775. The reason given was that included in the picture was a nude caricature of the Swiss painter Angelica Kauffman. This was subsequently painted over, but the original figure can still be seen in a sketch in Tate Britain. The true cause of offence, however, was that the picture was seen as an attack on Kauffman's friend Joshua Reynolds, President of the Royal Academy. His practice of borrowing poses from Old Master paintings to ennoble his portraits was seen by Hone as plagiarism.The model used for the figure of the conjuror was often employed by Reynolds. With his long cane the conjuror summons up an abundance of Old Master prints, while in his hand is a print of Raphael's 'Diadem Madonna'. The subject, 'Truth is revealed to Man', is a pointed reference to Reynold's artistic practice. After a brief showing at the Academy, it was requested that the painting be removed. Hone was furious, and promptly withdrew from the Royal Academy. Without delay he organised an indipendent display of his work, the first one-man show ever held in the British Isles.

Long Description: John was educated at Westminster School and then studied theology at Trinity College, Cambridge, where he graduated BA in 1754.[1] He became a fellow in 1755 and was ordained priest by 1757. An assistant master at Westminster School from 1757 to 1764, he acted as headmaster for three months in 1764 before becoming tutor to William Cavendish, 5th Duke of Devonshire from 1764 to 1766.[1] Vicar of Greenwich from 1766 to 1769, Hinchliffe was made a Chaplain to George III in 1768, and appointed Master of Trinity College in the same year.[1] In 1769 he was made Bishop of Peterborough. As bishop he played an active role in the House of Lords over the war with America.[1] In 1788 he resigned the Mastership of Trinity. From 1789 until his death Hinchliffe was Dean of Durham.He is buried in Peterborough Cathedral. The grave lies in a group of floor stones dedicated to bishops towards the east end.

Title: Judith and her Maidservant

Title: Chasse de danse

Keywords: Mary Cassatt, Cassat, Impresionism, Woman Bathing,

Title: Self Portrait in a Straw Hat

Title: Salisbury Cathedral from the Meadows

Long Description: John Constable has been able to produce sublime landscapes throughout his artistic career. The artist himself qualified himself as a painter of the natural history of the skies. His depictions were permeated with sentiment and sincerity.

Keywords: John Constable, Constable, Seascape Study with Rain Cloud, Romanticism, Landscape painting, Landscape, Oil on canvas, au plein air
Long Description: John Constable with this work anticipated Impressionism or even abstract art. He renewed landscape painting by painting "au plein air". To capture the ephemeral character of the skies, the artist painted fast like a camera.

Title: Salisbury Cathedral from the Bishop's Garden

Long Description: This is one of the paintings commissioned by Bishop John Fisher. John Constable included the bishop and his wife in the painting as a gesture of friendship. But they can hardly be seen since the artist portrayed nature as sublime, superior to the human being.

Long Description: John Constable made this painting as one of the seven "six-footers", referring to its monumental size, to achieve prestige and fortune. Considered one of the most popular English paintings, it gained the artist admission to the Royal Academy.

Title: Impression, soleil levant

Title: Luncheon on the Grass

Long Description: This painting by Claude Monet is presented for the first time at the Salon des Refusés. The work causes commotion by the loose brushwork that makes the figures look unfinished. But they have more vitality because of the more natural treatment of light.

Title: Madame Monet en costume japonais
Short description: Portrait of Camille Doncieux as a Japanese woman by Claude Monet
Keywords: Claude Monet, Monet,Madame Monet en costume japonais, Impressionism, Camille, Camille Doncieux, Kimono, Japanese, Japanese Painting, Impressionism Painting, Oil on Canvas
Long Description: Japanese culture was one of the main inspirations for Claude Monet and in Paris in general after the presence of Japan at the Universal Exposition in that city. In this work, Monet portrays his wife, Camille, in a kimono, a traditional Japanese dress.

Title: Woman in the Garden

Long Description: Claude Monet portrayed his cousin, Jeanne Marguerite Lecadre, in the garden of Le Havre, his home. At that time, the artist focused on women posing in gardens. He portrayed the beauty of nature with short brushstrokes and impasto.

Title: Garden at Sainte-Adresse

Long Description: Claude Monet spent the summer with his family at Sainte-Adresse, a seaside resort on the English Channel coast. The painting is an ode to sunny days on the coast of Normandy, France, portraying the vacations of the French bourgeoisie in the 1860s.

Title: La Grenouillère

Long Description: La Grenouillère, a restaurant on the island, was one of the artists' favorite places. Monet presents in the center of the composition the floating circular dish known as "Camembert" because of its shape. The contrast of light gives it a realistic effect.

Title: The Magpie

Long Description: This painting by Monet was created when Impressionism did not even exist. However, the artist began to observe the ephemeral in nature. We can see how he tried to capture each instant as something unique and unrepeatable through nuances and light effects.

Title: Springtime

Long Description: Claude Monet, the greatest representative of Impressionism, was obsessed with light in painting. Using small brushstrokes in a variety of colors he created images of trees, cathedrals or water surfaces as if they were part of the air and sky.

Title: The Cliffs at Étretat
Short description: View of the French city of Étretat by Claude Monet

Title: Poppies

Keywords: Claude Monet, Monet,Poppies, Argenteuil, Impressionism, Landscape, Landscape Painting, French Painting, Impressionism Painting, Oil on Canvas
Long Description: Flowers were the most repetitive motif in Monet's work. One of his most creative periods was when he lived in the French town of Argenteuil. He lived there for seven years and its landscapes were the perfect settings to capture the best colors.

Title: Woman with a Parasol

Keywords: Claude Monet, Monet, Woman with a Parasol, Camille, Camille Doncieux, Monet's wife, Impressionism, Landscape, Landscape Painting, French Painting, Impressionism Painting, Oil on Canvas
Long Description: One of the most remembered works of Claude Monet. In this painting he portrays his wife, Camille, and their son. It was painted in the town of Promenade. Today it is exhibited in the National Gallery of Art Museum in Washington.

Title: Pont d'Argenteuil
Short description: Painting by Claude Monet of Argenteuil, French town where he lived
Keywords: Claude Monet, Monet, Pont d'Argenteuil, Argenteuil, Impressionism, Landscape, Landscape Painting, French Painting, Impressionism Painting, Oil on Canvas
Long Description: Monet's time in Argenteuil was very productive, producing some of his best works. In this painting the artist demonstrates his ability to capture how objects change depending on the incidence of light.

Title: Le Grand Canal

Keywords: Claude Monet, Monet, The Grand Canal, Le Grand Canal, Venice, Venice canal, Impressionism, Landscape, Landscape Painting, French Painting, Impressionism Painting, Oil on Canvas
Long Description: Claude Monet portrayed the Venice canal in a unique way. A standard bearer of modern painting, the artist uses the water line to divide the canvas in two. The whole scene is bathed in a peculiar light with unnaturalistic nuances.

Title: Water Lily Pond
Short description: Impressionist painting of the water park at Giverny by Claude Monet
Keywords: Claude Monet, Monet, Giverny, Water Lily Pond, Lilies, Giverty Garden, Impressionism, Landscape, Landscape Painting, French Painting, Water Painting, Impressionism Painting, Oil on Canvas
Long Description: Claude Monet lived his last years in Giverny, a French town. There he recreated a Japanese garden, including a lake and aquatic flowers, and captured it in all his last paintings. As his blindness increased, his brushstrokes became more and more abstract.

Title: Camille Monet on a Bench
Short description: Portrait of Camille Doncieux, Monet's wife, sitting on a garden bench with a letter in her hand.

Long Description: This work was painted the same year that Camille's father passed away, which can be reflected in her sad gaze. The person behind her has been interpreted in various ways, from being the messenger of death to a neighbor offering condolences.

Title: Music in the Tuileries

Long Description: Édouard Manet followed in the footsteps of the poet Baudelaire and  followed his advice and began to paint subjects of modern life, moving away from classical themes. The passion for Velázquez appears in this work combining tradition and modernity.

Title: Luncheon on the Grass
Short description: This painting by Édouard Manet was a scandal
Keywords: Édouard Manet, Manet, Luncheon on the Grass, Impressionism, Impressionism Painting, Oil on Canvas, National Gallery, Daily Life Painting, Landscape, Landscape Painting, Modern Art, Modern Painting, Modern Life
Long Description: A naked woman picnicking next to two clothed men was a scandal. Moreover, it is a huge canvas, a size reserved for large subjects. Édouard Manet anticipated Impressionism by challenging the limits of traditional art.

Title: Olympia

Long Description: This painting by Manet caused a great scandal as the French Academy considered that it was badly painted and also, that it was immoral. Nudes usually depicted goddesses but Manet portrayed an upper class Parisian prostitute.

Title: Berthe Morisot With a Bouquet of Violets

Long Description: Édouard Manet portrayed Berthe Morisot, a key artist of Impressionism, on several occasions. They began their friendship in the late 60s. Morisot later married the painter's brother.

Title: At the Café

Keywords: Édouard Manet, Manet, At the Café, Impressionism, Impressionism Painting, Oil on Canvas, Daily Life Painting, Modern Art, Modern Painting
Long Description: Manet shows an everyday situation of the Parisian nights of the time: wealthy gentlemen attending the famous cabarets of the city. A characteristic of this work is the solitude of the characters, none of them look at each other.

Title: Le Chemin de fer (The Railway)

Keywords: Édouard Manet, Manet, Le Chemin de fer, The Railway, Impressionism, Impressionism Painting, Oil on Canvas, Daily Life Painting, Modern Art, Modern Painting , National Gallery
Long Description: This is Manet's last painting featuring his favorite model, the painter Victorine Meurent. She also posed for his most famous works, including Luncheon on the Grass and Olympia, his most controversial work.

Title: Nymph Surprised

Long Description: Painted by Édouard Manet, this work was modeled on Suzanne Manet, the artist's sentimental companion. The piece was originally intended as part of a more ambitious composition in which Moses saved from the waters was to be represented.

Title: Kearsarge-Alabama

Long Description: This work by Manet is based on the Battle of Cherbourg, a ship fight during the American Civil War, where the USS Kearsarge sank the CSS Alabama. The artist relied on newspaper descriptions to depict the event.

Title: Chez Père Lathuille

Long Description: Manet portrayed a couple on the terrace of the restaurant Père Lathuille. It is an image of modern life featuring Louis Gauthier Lathuille, son of the restaurant's owner, and actress Ellen Andrée.

Title: A Bar at the Folies-Bergère

Keywords: Édouard Manet, Manet, A Bar at the Folies-Bergère, Impressionism, Impressionism Painting, Oil on Canvas, Daily Life Painting, Modern Art, Modern Painting
Long Description: This was Manet's last work and for many it was his best work. It is inspired by modern Parisian life, his favorite subject par excellence. Manet demonstrated his skills in optical effects in the reflection of the mirror creating a novel point of view.

Title: Young Flautist, or The Fifer

Title: Nana

Long Description: One of the various interpretations of this work by Manet is that it depicts a prostitute and her client behind her. After being rejected by the Salon de Paris, Manet exhibited the painting in the window of a shop on one of the main streets of Paris.

Long Description: The Kiss is Gustav Klimt's best known work and an Austrian national treasure. It depicts two life-size lovers who are surrounded by gold. It is a clear example of Klimt's "Golden Period", inspired by the Byzantine mosaics that had impressed him.

Title: Judith II (Salome)

Long Description: Klimt depicted Judith, known as Salome; a biblical figure who beheaded General Holofernes who threatened to invade the Jewish people. Klimt portrays her holding her head and as a more harmful, aggressive and daring woman than she is usually depicted.

Title: Portrait of Adele Bloch-Bauer I

Title: Farm Garden with Sunflowers

Title: Stoclet Palace

Title: Schubert at the Piano

Title: Judith I

Long Description: image seen of Luna Park where the buildings have been afixed with lights of different shapes to outline the architecture
